awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Testing New Formulae for Pressure Derivatives of Specific Heat, Thermal Conductivity, and Thermal Diffusivity
awd_abstract_narration:
Heat flow is ubiquitous. How efficiently matter transports heat is of fundamental importance. Understanding heat transport is critical to numerous engineering and scientific endeavors, such as designing tiny electronic devices or modeling the cooling rate of large planetary bodies. The most accurate method for measuring heat transport properties (laser-flash analysis) has shown that values from diverse types of solids depend on the length over which heat is flowing. Static properties (e.g., density) do not behave in this manner, so tests against length were not made earlier. This finding led to new formulae describing thermal dynamic behavior (conductivity, diffusivity, and heat capacity) as functions of pressure. The formulae describe steady-state conditions. This contrasts with equations of classical thermodynamics developed in the 1800s to describe idealizations such as constant temperature. These findings are critical for Geophysics because matter in Earth’s deep interior is under extreme pressures. Here, the researchers will further test the formulation which they previously validated for a limited number of solids and over a limited range of temperature.  They now quantify heat properties in a wider range of solids, and other states of matter, and over a greater temperature range. They use a new laser flash apparatus for liquids (water in particular); the new apparatus allows measuring heat capacity and attains low temperature. They re-analyze data on gases available in the literature. The goal is extreme accuracy in the measurement, notably that of initial slope and temperatures near ambient conditions.  Both the old and the new formulation for thermal properties are tested. This project may initiate a paradigm shift in the way we quantify heat flow. Its outcomes improve our understanding of the microscopic mechanism responsible for it. They have potentially wide repercussions for pure and applied physical sciences. The project also supports a female scientist with disability and provides training to undergraduate students at University of Washington.  

Discovery that thermal diffusivity (D) and thermal conductivity (k) of insulators, semi-conductors, metals, alloys, and glasses depends on the length-scale (L) of measurements has repercussions for pure and applied physical sciences. Linear dependence on L for small length-scales agrees with dimensional analysis of Fourier’s heat equation. It shows that results from diamond anvil cell experiments are problematic, foremost because these are benchmarked against 1 atm data for L > 100 times larger.  Reliable data below 2 GPa pressure exist on mm-sized samples from well-worn methods. Analyzing these results for 25 solids of diverse bond type show that the logarithmic pressure derivative of specific heat (cP) equals -1 times the linear compressibility. Mathematical analysis allowing for k depending on L (i.e., volume) also related its logarithmic pressure response to equation-of-state properties, and likewise for D. The new k vs. P formula was confirmed against reliable data for 20 solids. Therefore, the team’s preliminary tests suggest, but do not prove, that the new formulae are thermodynamic identities describing steady-state conditions, which is a commonly encountered restriction. Isothermal is not, because thermal emissions are ubiquitous. Thus, the time-independent formulations from classical thermodynamics do not describe properly the time-depended conditions in the Earth where heat is flowing. To test the new formula for cP vs. P, databases already in existence can be used. Since a generally applicable formula for steady state is the goal, diverse states of matter and bond type are being tested. The researchers also collect data on liquids and ices (e.g., water, metals melting near 298 K). They use a new laser flash apparatus – the LFA467 instrument and its commercial low-pressure cell to 10 MPa - covering ~100 to 500°C, that simultaneously measures D and cP.  Spurious radiative transfer is removed via coating the interior of the cell with graphite. A dilatometer spanning this T range is used when density vs T is not available, to constrain k. Using machine learning to parameterize cP, D, and k vs. P, L, T, will either distinguishing whether the new or previous formulae are correct, or will lead to new and accurate formulae, permitting extrapolation to high pressure inside Earth. Thus, the proposed work provides basic physics that is essential to Geophysics. Confirmed P derivatives of cP and k (or D) pertain to any process inside Earth and other large bodies. The work outcomes lead to improving accuracy of geophysical and petrologic models and has potential to improve our understanding of planetary interiors.  Since new thermodynamic identities have not been developed for ~100 years, other physical sciences, such as study of chemical reactions, may be impacted.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to improve understanding of heat transport properties especially of solids. Heat transfer largely controls the time evolution of the Earth, planets, and stars.  How quickly heat moves through matter is described by thermal diffusivity (D) whereas thermal conductivity (K) describes how much heat is moved, and is the product of D times specific heat (cp) times density.  Heat always moves because this is pure energy which enters, goes through, and then exits solid material.  Yet, heat flow was neglected when classical thermodynamics was developed in the mid 1800's and so the equations used (e.g., for specific heat vs pressure) are not valid for diverse situations, especially those deep inside a planet. Moreover, thermodynamics is based on gas behavior (Figure 1) and neglects solids being rigid, which permits heat to flow through a solid. A third, related problem is that thermodynamics is based on entropy, which is the ratio of stored heat to temperature in the basic equations of thermodynamics.  Stored heat is that which cannot flow, which underscores that classical thermodynamics omits key behaviors. Assuming equilibrium is recognized as inexact, but convenient.

The project addresses the omissions by considering steady-state conditions which are realistic and achievable, along with Fourier's 1822 theory for heat transfer, and Stephan-Boltzmann's 1879 equation relating temperature to heat flux (not stored heat). Many new equations were derived.  All formulae were confirmed by available measurements in the literature and by our own measurements of D, using laser flash analysis.  The LFA technique is the most accurate of all methods for D or K (+/-2 to 3%) due to knowing the distance over which heat travels and to solving Fourier's equation directly and simply. Recent developments in LFA by the materials science community now provide accurate data for transparent glasses and minerals.  

LFA data show that D is a function of sample length for thin samples, which is demonstrated by dimensional analysis of Fourier's equations. This was not recognized earlier because many modern techniques presume thickness. From Fourier's equations we derived an identity for the pressure dependence of K. By considering that adding small amounts of heat expands the solid incrementally, a change opposed by rigidity (i.e., Young's modulus or strength) of solids, we derived formula that connect Young's modulus, density, thermal expansivity, and specific heat.  This connection explains why thermal expansivity is proportional to specific heat at low temperature, but gradually changes to linear proportionality with temperature as T climbs and the solid weakens.We also showed that isothermal and adiabatic (designated as constant entropy in classical thermodynamics) are identical within uncertainty, and provided a new pressure derivative for specific heat. The most recent paper documents a new connection between changes in thermal diffusivity and changes in specific heat.  The experimental results and theoretical findings support diffusion of radiation as the microscopic mechanism for heat transfer, which was quantified in our earlier spectroscopic model.

            New formulae and new realizations from our combined experimental and analytical theoretical approach to uniting heat transfer and thermodynamics were published in the materials science literature to make these accessible beyond earth science, as the results are general.  We also applied our results to the Earth (a solid) and to the Sun (gas to solid) in published papers.  Combining our result for the pressure dependence of thermal conductivity with seismic data on Earth's bulk modulus (inverse of compressibility) shows that a thermal maximum exists in the lower mantle. Temperatures are high were the heat source lies.  The mantle both insulates Earth's barren core while its small proportion of radiogenic isotopes causes the core to melt. By combining Fourier's theory with Stefan-Boltzmann's law, temperatures are constrained in large, spherical bodies under steady-state. The model has no free parameters and is entirely independent of gravitational compression of the interior of a star or planet.  On this basis, our model derived for the Sun applies to gas giants.  Thus, this project solved the major problem of interior temperatures for the largest bodies, with no free parameters.  Constraints are mass, radius and surface temperature for the stars, which are more-or-less homogeneous bodies. For a layered body, like Earth, some additional information is needed on the interior: seismic data is an important constraint and was utilized in our application papers.

                Our new formulae, findings, and results have broad applications that extend far beyond those explored during the project.  Accordingly, two review papers were written at the end of the project.
